sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Peptic ulcer disease; Adjunct: 25 to 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily with meals and at bedtime; begin with lowest dose and adjust based on clinical response

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy have not been established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: Geriatric: begin at the low end of the dosing range and titrate carefully

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• acute gastrointestinal hemorrhage with unstable cardiovascular status
  • allergic or idiosyncratic reactions to mepenzolate or related agents
  • gastrointestinal obstructive disease (eg, pyloroduodenal stenosis, achalasia)
  • glaucoma
  • intestinal atony of the elderly or debilitated
  • myasthenia gravis
  • obstructive uropathy
  • paralytic ileus
  • ulcerative colitis complicated by toxic megacolon

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- congestive heart failure
  • -- cardiac arrhythmias
  • -- coronary heart disease
  • -- hypertension
  • -- tachycardia; evaluate prior to administration; exacerbation may occur
  • Neurologic:
  • -- autonomic neuropathy
  • Endocrine/Metabolic:
  • -- decreased sweating may result in heat prostration, including heat stroke and fever, when environmental temperatures are high
  • -- hyperthyroidism
  • Gastrointestinal:
  • -- diarrhea may be an early symptom of incomplete gastrointestinal obstruction (inappropriate use), especially in patients with ileostomy or colostomy
  • -- gastric ulcer therapy (off-label use); complications (antral statis) may occur due to delayed gastric emptying
  • -- hiatal hernia associated with reflux esophagitis
  • -- ulcerative colitis; large doses may suppress intestinal mobility leading to paralytic ileus and precipitation or aggravation of toxic megacolon
  • Hepatic:
  • -- hepatic disease
  • Immunologic:
  • -- allergic-type reactions may occur in tartrazine-sensitive patients, especially those who also have aspirin sensitivity
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- blurred vision may occur
  • Other:
  • -- elderly; dose adjustment may be required
  • Psychiatric:
  • -- psychosis has been reported
  • Renal:
  • -- renal disease
  • Reproductive:
  • -- prostatic hypertrophy

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Mepenzolate: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Mepenzolate bromide is a postganglionic parasympathetic inhibitor that decreases gastric acid and pepsin secretions and suppresses spontaneous colonic contractions.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono: Renal: 3% to 22% over 5 days, with the majority appearing on day 1

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in symptoms of peptic ulcers indicates efficacy.
  • tachycardia prior to administration; additional increase in heart rate may occur

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may impair heat regulation due to decreased sweating. Advise patient to use caution with activities leading to an increased core temperature, such as strenuous exercise, exposure to extreme heat, or dehydration
  • Patient should avoid driving or other activities that require clear vision until drug effects are realized.
  • Tell patient to report diarrhea, especially those with ileostomy or colostomy.
  • Counsel patient to report CNS symptoms (eg, psychosis, confusion, disorientation, short-term memory loss, euphoria, hallucinations, dysarthria, ataxia, fatigue, insomnia, agitation, lowered anxiety).
  • Side effects may include blurred vision, vomiting, nausea, constipation, loss of taste, bloating, dry mouth, dizziness, weakness, drowsiness, headache, urticaria, anaphylaxis, urinary hesitancy or retention, impotence, or lactation suppression.
  • Patient should not use antacids while taking this drug.
